text: In a "futuristic" 1920s laboratory, a man in tail coat an bow tie is being tortured. Ultrasound is being piped into ears. It's incredibly painful! He's screaming. Title card: I'm not telling!   I won't talk!!! His torturers, cold men of science in white coats, gradua increase the volume. The pain seems unbearable, the volum reaches level 10 (maximum), the man passes out!

Guards wearing long leather overcoats throw the man into cell! As the man is lying there on the ground, a dog wiggles through the bars at the window. The dog, a Jack Russell, jumps on top of the man - visibly his master - and begins lick his face. The man opens one eye! When he sees his do he can't help cracking a smile... The man, now on his feet, looks in pain. Despite the pain motions to his dog who begins to bark in lively fashion. Outside the cell, the guard looks curious about the noise goes to the door, opens the spy flap and finds himself fa to face with the man, eye to eye just a couple of inches apart! The man moves his eyes in such a way that he hypnotizes the guard! Superimposed on the screen: a spinn black and white spiral, until the dazed guard take his ke opens the door and releases the man and his dog.

The man (the hero, thus) imprisons the guard without harm him, then runs over to the guard's desk. His ears are sti causing him pain, but he opens a drawer and takes out his belongings: a top hat which he snaps open, and a mask, wh he puts over his head to conceal his eyes. We catch up with the masked man walking down corridors. H suddenly stops, copied by his dog who follows him like hi shadow. The man, on his guard, has spotted another guard where two corridors meet. With a look, he orders his dog to move forwards into the guard's line of sight. The guard looks over at the animal Using his fingers, the hero pretends to shoot his dog. Th dog collapses, plays dead. The guard, increasingly curiou gets to his feet. He slowly approaches the motionless dog When he comes close he is attacked from the side by the h who quickly puts him out of action with a mere punch! The masked man then rushes to another cell, and releases young female prisoner. She too is wearing evening dress. she is thanking him he staggers and clutches his ears in pain. She's concerned. Title card: Can I help you in some way? He refuses. Title card: No. I don't get helped.   I give the help around here. He composes himself. She casts him an admiring glance. Th in view of the urgency of their situation, they escape at run.
They come out of a house that is lost in the hills, climb into a Bugatti sports car that the man starts by rubbing wires together, and speed off.
The car speeds along the road. Its occupants turn round t check they aren't being followed.
The guard who got knocked out picks himself up, realizes happened and dashes over to his office. He grabs a radio emitter and begins sending a message.

The hero, the young woman and the dog come to a halt in t Bugatti on the air field, by a telegraph pole whose wires lead...to a watch tower. In the watch tower, a radio receptor is vibrating. A sold approaches, listens and suddenly understands! He grabs ho his gun and goes out onto the air field, only to find the fugitives! He tries to shoot at them as he draws closer, the hero manages to throw an airplane propeller at him, b climbing inside where the woman and dog are waiting for h The airplane begins to move. The soldier shoots. The airplane is positioning itself on the runway, while t soldier continues to fire! The aircraft gains speed. The soldier is still shooting, but too late, as the heroo back the joystick, and the airplane takes to the sky... The soldier is furious, but the hero is all smiles as he back towards the ground and shouts something. Title card: Free Georgia forever!!! The airplane flies away into the evening sky.

A little later in the night, still at the controls, the m fighting not to fall asleep. Behind him, the women is sle the dog is lying in her arms. Suddenly she is awoken by explosions happening close by! Pandemonium! The man doesn understand it either, he tries to pick up altitude, but q notices that the explosions are in fact pretty and inoffensive. He consults a calendar dial on the control p that shows it is July 14th, immediately understands, and bursts into laughter. Title card: We've arrived, welcome to France!!!
As the music picks up the tune of The Marseillaise, the airplane flies away through the exploding fireworks... The words "The End" appear on the screen.

From the moment they parked the car onwards, we become absorbed by what's happening around the screening of end this film. Behind the screen, we've seen the actor who plays the her his name is George Valentin - closely studying the reacti of the audience. He was standing close to his dog, motion to it not to make a noise. The dog's name is Jack. In the same area, we've also seen the lead actress. Her n is Constance Gray. She too looks tense and is latched ont the arm of a pleasant-looking man who is chewing anxiousl a cigar. The man looks rich, but a little weak. He's sure the producer.

In the house, much of the audience is open-mouthed, excit immobile and often wide-eyed. In the pit, a symphony orchestra plays to accompany the f (9) Now that the film is ending, and the last note is sounding, the cast anxiously awaits the audience's verdic which, after two or three seconds of silence, bursts into thunderous applause, to the great joy of the actor and th people around him, especially the actress and the produce who kiss each other on the lips. Two theater hands bring down the curtain. (10) The lights come on. George Valentin comes onto the s and acknowledges the audience, they are cheering for him. is so happy he dances a few tap steps to express his joy he acknowledges the orchestra before finally motioning to someone in the wings to join him. Jack the dog trots over response. The crowd laughs and cheers, George waves to th dog, Jack waves back then waves at the audience, the peop are loving it! In the wings, Constance is fuming with rage, but on stage George is pretending with his fingers to pull at the dog, fakes death. Thunderous applause again.

Behind the actress, the producer can't hold back a smile, this enrages the actress still more. Suddenly, George, hamming it up, remembers something he'd forgotten, and asks someone from the other side of the wi to join him. It's Constance. She comes over, smiling to t audience, and says something to George with a smile. Title card: I'll get you for that. She waves, but we can tell that her smile is set between teeth. She isn't feeling comfortable. George motions firi gun with his fingers, but she does not fall down, merely casts him a "very funny" glance. George looks at his fing not understanding why they don't work anymore then mimes throwing them away behind him, as though they've become useless. Constance stalks back off into the wings in annoyance, but the audience is ecstatic. Once in the wing the actress sticks up her middle finger at George, and exaggeratedly mouths so he can read her lips: "Put this u your ass." George, grinning broadly, responds by clapping hands in applause, then leaves the stage, executing a few more dance steps as he does so. The audience is delighted As he comes off stage, George gets soundly told off by Constance, but, still grinning, he motions towards the audience who are still asking for more. The producer, although delighted by the successful reception, makes a w attempt to calm the actress down. As for George, he retur to the stage, the audience roars. He pretends to want to leave the stage, and mimes bumping into an invisible wall just as he's leaving the stage. George holds his nose, th audience goes wild, Constance gets even madder, and while George carries on clowning about, the producer too breaks into a beaming smile. He's probably realized that George the audience on his side... Constance, furious, storms of is followed by the producer who is trying to placate her, although it looks like he's got his work cut out for him.

Outside, we are in front of a typically American movie th decked out with all the accessories of a grand premiere. entrance is lit up, there are crowds gathered on the side cops are guarding the red carpet with a cordon of bodies, George comes out, causing the crowds, mainly young women, press forwards - and the photographers' flashes to spark life. The cops are struggling to maintain control of the situation as George poses for the photographers and waves his many fans.

In the crowd, a young woman right at the front is staring him in rapture. She drops her bag and, as she bends to pi up, a swell in the crowd pushes her underneath the arms o policeman in front of her, out of the crowd and into Geor She stares at him, more in love than ever, delighted to b there. The police wait for someone to give orders. George doesn't quite know what to do. Nobody moves. The young wo finally bursts out laughing, which, after a moment of sho causes George to laugh too, thus placating the cops and t signaling to the photographers that they can take picture the scene. The flashes seem to lend the woman self-confid who, in a very carefree manner, begins to clown about in of them. George is delighted at the sight, by the whole s and, realizing this, the young woman steals a kiss. Flash image becomes static, then dissolves into the printed pic on the front page of "The Hollywood Reporter" newspaper, with three other pictures of the scene and the headline W

The very same newspaper is being read by an elegant woman sitting at a sumptuous breakfast table. We are in the lar dining room of an ultra-luxurious Hollywood villa. All ar her are magnificent furniture, superb paintings and objet d'art, including a beautiful trio of monkeys, one hiding eyes, one with hands clasped to its ears and the third obscuring its mouth. George comes into the room and kisse his wife. She responds with cold indifference. You could the atmosphere with a knife. The woman hands George the newspaper. He knows what's up but tries to laugh it off. doesn't find it funny, is as cold as stone and barely loo at him. She is obviously extremely annoyed with him. Geor picks up his dog and puts it on the table. Jack drops his head to one side and his big eyes implore seem to implore forgiveness. It's the exact expression of someone asking be loved, but Doris is implacable. She gets up, walks awa and does not turn back. Left on his own, George has a clo expression on his face. He seems unhappy to have hurt his wife's feelings. Then he realizes that Jack is on the tab in a ridiculous pose, and signals to him to get down. The obeys. George looks at the paper, the cause of his proble
Thirteen white letters placed on a hillside. HOLLYWOODLAND. Below, in town, a bus.

Inside the full bus is the young woman from the day befor name is Peppy Miller. She is proudly holding "The Hollywo Reporter" with her face on the front page, and is more or discreetly making suggestive glances, hoping that someone recognizes her. But the people around her - from working middle class backgrounds - are visibly on their way to wo remain impervious to her game. She - carefully - puts the paper away in her bag, in whic or five copies of the newspaper are already carefully tuc away, then gets off the bus at the next stop.

She goes through the main gates of Kinograph Studios, and heads towards where they hire extras. In a courtyard, fifty-odd people are waiting, some sittin wooden crates, others standing. There are mums with kids, guys with animals, men dressed as cowboys, etc. Peppy is among them, sitting next to a man of about sixty who is dressed in a highly stylized fashion. His job is obviousl that of a butler. Peppy proudly shows him the picture in newspaper. The man leans to take a closer look, unfolds t newspaper, sees the headline, smiles and then folds it ba up again and returns it to Peppy text-side-up, highlighti the headline: Who's that girl ? Peppy is a bit annoyed to have been put in her place, but deep down she knows he's right. Nobody knows who she is. puts the newspaper away. A man who visibly works for the studio, some assistant or other, comes into the courtyard, climbs on a crate and ma an announcement. Title card: Contemporary film!   Five girls who can dance All the men who had pressed forwards turn on their heels, leaving the assistant surrounded only by women. The man s something to one girl, who begins to dance. He motions to that it's ok and she heads off towards the wardrobe secti He does the same with a second girl and she gets hired to Then it's Peppy's turn. She puts a lot of energy into a f top class tap steps, impressing the guy to such an extent that he smiles admiringly then signals that she's hired. Full of self-assurance that her lucky day has come, Peppy heads off towards wardrobe too; swinging, her hips as she pauses in front of the butler.
Title card: The name is Miller.    Peppy Miller! She finishes with an exaggerated wink, before walking on, leaving behind the impassive butler.

In the lobby, George is preparing to leave the house. He waves at the huge, full-length portrait of himself waving smiling whilst wearing a tuxedo. He looks great in the painting, and George is delighted to see and to wave to himself.
Later, George, in a luxurious car driven by his chauffeur arrives at the Kinograph studios with his dog. The guard entrance smiles broadly at them and waves.
As he walks towards his dressing room, everyone smiles at He's not always fooled by these signs of respect, and ape few smiles himself.

In his dressing room, wearing a tailcoat and top hat, Geo is finishing putting his make up on. He has a white face dark lips and eyes. His chauffeur is signing autographs f him on full length photographs of himself (George) with h dog. George says to him: Title card: Go and buy a piece of jewelry for my wife. A piece, to make it up to her. The chauffeur nods. Having finished his mask up, George, picks up a photo, looks at it closely and then writes on As he leaves the dressing room, we see the photograph. He written Woof Woof on it, and signed it with the paw print a dog.
We're on a film set, the crew is setting up a shot. The director is unhappy with a screen positioned behind a bay window and he sends it off.

Title card: Remove that screen and bring me another one! the double! Two hands pick up the screen and carry it away. George arrives on set, everyone smiles at him. He sits down on t chair which bears his name. The producer whom we saw the previous day at the premiere arrives. His name is Zimmer, he's flanked by - and followed around at every moment by two secretaries and two assistants. One of them hands him Hollywood Reporter, and Zimmer, before he's even come to halt, talks to George as he shows him the front page. He visibly upset. George looks a lot more relaxed, he says h and vaguely tries to reassure him. But Zimmer persists, s pointing at the newspaper. Title card: Because of this childish nonsense, there's nothing about the film before page 5! Behind George, the two set hands come back with a new scr of sky scenery, and wait, standing just next to George. A they are holding it, there is a three foot gap underneath While the producer is talking to him, George's attention drawn by a lovely pair of women's legs that have come to stand behind the screen, the top half of the body being hidden by it. George acknowledges the sight with a smile is about to bring his attention back to the on-going discussion, when his attention is drawn away again by a noise, that of the tap steps the female legs are making, presumably as a warm up. George smiles in recognition and responds with a few tap steps of his own. The women's leg instantly stop, seem to think a moment and then answer ba but with a jump in the complexity of the steps. A tap dialogue ensues between the two pairs of legs, until the hands - the path before them now cleared - pick up their screen of scenery and walk off with it. The screen moves and as it disappears reveals that the upper body belongs young woman. She pulls a face meaning 'Here I am!!' And o course it's Peppy, except that she immediately realizes w she is dealing with - visibly she wasn't expecting this a all - and feels completely ridiculous and uncomfortable. Her joyful expression gradually becomes one of abject apology, but George is roaring with laughter. After a short pause, Zimmer makes the connection. He chec the front page of the paper, and recognizes her! Then he begins shouting at her and all she can do is lowe her head, unable to reply. He gestures that she's fired a for her to get out, and she starts to go, completely distraught. She's just made a couple of steps when George stops her and tells her to come back. Everyone is surpris most of all him. Zimmer can't believe it, and so doesn't respond at first.

There's bad feeling between them, as though neither wante this sudden conflict, but like it had always been there, tangible. Everyone on the set seems to be waiting for Zim to react, but to their surprise, after a long moment of hesitation, he walks away without saying a thing. Peppy l at George gratefully, smiling, but seems a little preoccu as though she might have made a mistake. Everyone on set gets back to work.

They're about to start shooting. The director is showing George what he has to do. The scene is happening in a cab restaurant. George has to cross a dance floor, but each t is stopped by a guy ringing a bell to signal it is time t change dancing partner. George finds himself dancing with Peppy one moment, and in the arms of a very fat man the n the director finds the gag hysterical. The scene is shot several times from three different angles. Each time, Geo dances with Peppy, and, each time, the nature of their ra changes. To begin with, they are happy and laughing, but with time, less so. Then they become embarrassed, and the things get worse. We start the sequence again and again, sound of the clapperboard counting the number of takes, b eroticism between them is the only thing that stands out the scene, every thing else goes unnoticed. Ultimately, n flirting or suggestiveness has gone on, just the very obv beginning of feelings between them that they find disturb It's probably love.

Later on, in the dressing room corridor, Peppy, holding a envelope, goes up to George's door. She knocks, waits for reply, then enters. There's nobody there. She hesitates, sure whether to leave or stay...

Finally, she goes into the room and places the envelope addressed to George Valentin on the dresser. Then she attentively looks around the dressing room. She looks at objects and photos and notices, hanging from a coat stand George's jacket on a hanger, and his hat which sits on a above it. The way the clothes are disposed looks like Geo silhouette, except that the clothes are empty. She goes o strokes the jacket and little by little brings George to through his clothes.

She puts her right hand into the sleeve and touches her o waist. As it's George's sleeve, she makes it look like hi has come to life, as though George has come to life. Even so since her left hand is stroking the jacket as though G were inside. She takes pleasure from the embrace and, whe George comes into the room, she slowly removes her hand w any rush. George sees her, they look at each other. He cl the door but doesn't go over to her, instead going over t mirror. He looks at her, she at him... He motions to her approach. She does. He stares at her face for a while bef speaks. Title card: If you want to be an actress, you need to hav something no one else has. He takes a make-up pencil and draws a beauty spot above h upper lip. She looks at herself in the mirror and smiles. likes it. She turns towards him and, quite naturally, fol into his arms. The dog watches them curiously with its he leaning to one side. They are probably about to kiss when George's chauffeur comes into the room and catches them. George swiftly moves aside and there is a moment of discomfort. The chauffeur unwraps a parcel and takes out large and beautiful pearl necklace. George is intrigued b the necklace, and turns away from Peppy. She understands George has his own life, that their embrace was just a st moment and slowly leaves, looking back at George as she d so. He does not look at her. She leaves the room. Once he studied and necklace and is satisfied, George turns back towards Peppy but she is no longer there. The chauffeur e the room. When he is alone, George looks at himself in the mirror. expression shows that he things he is the stupidest man i the world. He mimes shooting himself in the temple with h fingers, but it's the dog which collapses into its play-d pose.

The next morning, he's having breakfast with his wife. Th atmosphere is still dreadful but this time he's not makin effort either. He disdainfully watches Doris eat. She is cutting up strawberries using a knife and fork. George wa her, smiles and continues to watch. Except it's not Doris watching. Instead it's Peppy who's tucking into her food talking and laughing vivaciously. George is with her with expression of love on his face. He's laughing with her wh suddenly, reality bites. He's still sitting opposite Dori and she's staring at him because she doesn't understand w is laughing. She visibly finds him ridiculous. He stops laughing and breakfast carries on as normal.

We see several quick sequences which indicate time passin Breakfasts with George and Doris where the atmosphere is increasingly dreadful. Doris scribbles on photos of Georg the press, draws on moustaches, large spectacles, etc.
Short extracts of George in various films, in which he po a pirate, then a cowboy, then William Tell, etc. We also him in "Someday in July" in the sequence he shot with Pep the fat male dancer.

Movie-goers reacting to the films, but the way the images edited - cut with breakfast images - could mean they are reacting to them too. Among the audience is Peppy Miller. She's trying to concentrate fully on the film and is pushing away the han young man she's with, who is trying to kiss her. We see h later, at the movies again, but this time alone. 27   INT. STUDIO/STAGES - PEPPY AS A SERVANT/DANCER/ETC. We see her playing some bit parts, maid, dancer, etc. Her seem to get a little bigger. We notice that she now wears beauty spot that she'll keep forever. Her name climbs up the ranks in the title sequences of fi until it appears on its own.
We see her signing a contract in a small office, she seem happy. 29
George signs a big contract with Zimmer as photographers pictures. He smiles broadly, whereas Zimmer looks like hi smile is a little forced. The date appears on the screen: 1929

George, dressed as a musketeer, is sword-fighting with th middle-ages thugs in a tavern. He kills two of them, but unfortunately loses his epee when fighting the third. But the third man attacks, George merely dodges with a sleigh body and puts his attacker out of action with a right hoo Calm restored, he smiles and waves in brotherly fashion t mysterious man who is trying to hide underneath his long The man stands up, throws aside his cape and reveals hims be... Napoleon! He puts his bicorne hat back on and warml thanks an astonished George. Napoleon says something to h and George respectfully bows, walks away from him still b then turns and runs. Once out of the decor, he bumps righ a worried-looking Zimmer who is followed by his loyal assistants. George is in a playful mood. Zimmer tells him Title Card: I want to show you something.     Right now. George seems astonished that Zimmer is leaving the set an not filming, but agrees. Napoleon walks past them very imperially and gestures royally to a technician to bring a chair. The technician doesn't miss the chance to remind man that he is only an extra, and not Napoleon. 31

Zimmer, his guards, and George - still dressed as a muske come into a screening room in which a dozen or so very se looking people are waiting. They sit down and Zimmer, ver proudly and self-confidently, gestures to an assistant wh passes on the message to the projectionist. The room goes The screening begins. 32

On screen we see a card that indicates it's a sound shoot test for a talking scene. Then Constance appears, the act from the spy film. She's standing in front of a mic and s tests it, delighted to be there. Cut. We see her again, t microphone has disappeared and she acts out a scene. It's monologue. Her acting is terrible, very theatrical, but t audience can hear her. It is however, awful. (31) In the screening room, the audience seems stunned by what they see/hear. They are fascinated. They then begin congratulate each other and slap Zimmer on the back. Zimm pride seems to grow by the second. George, who at first seemed very surprised, slowly begins snigger which gradually has become a belly laugh when the actress earnestly ends her monologue.

When the lights come up, George is laughing uncontrollabl way beyond the bounds of mere mockery as his sincerity is obvious. The people present are embarrassed, and Zimmer i deeply put out. George, still laughing, leaves the room, waving an apology with his hands as he goes, but also pointing to the screen to explain why he's laughing. Zimm feels even more humiliated. Fade to black on his face.

We're back with George in his dressing room. He's removin make up. He moves some ordinary object and the object, as moves it, makes a noise. We hear the noise it makes. Real hear it. It's the first time we've heard a sound that com from within the film itself. One second later, George rea that the object made a noise. He moves it again, the obje makes a noise again. George is worried. He tries another and obtains noise again. His dog barks and we hear it! He up (chair makes a noise) and says something to his dog, b sound comes out of his mouth when he speaks. He realizes this... Panic sets in, he turns to the mirror and tries t again, but still no sound comes out. Not understanding wh happening, the feeling of panic fully blossoms and he fle dressing room!

Noisy, laughing dancers pass in the corridor, others are talking or shouting and even if we can't make out what th saying, they are all making sound. George tries to talk t but his voice remains silent. One dancer, seeing his frig bursts into throaty laughter. George rushes through the milling crowd the sound of which is becoming increasingly loud...

...and bursts out into the courtyard of the studio that i suddenly deserted and silent. In front of him a feather e slowly to the ground, carried by the breeze. It finally l making a completely abnormal and disproportionate noise l that of a building crashing to the ground in slow motion. George screams, but again his cry is silent.
George awakes with a start! He's in bed and is having tro shaking off his nightmare. The film continues as normal: in other words, silent.
His wife is sleeping by his side. He gets up, taking care to make a sound.
George calms down as he sits in the living room, alone in darkness. Jack, still sleepy, has just curled into a ball next to him to fall back to sleep. George smiles and give him a pat.
Driven by his chauffeur, George crosses town heading for studios. 39
The car goes through the studio gates. There's nobody the George gets out. He goes into the courtyard. There's nobo there either.
He goes into the studio and heads for the set. There is s no one about. He doesn't understand and goes back outside

Outside in the deserted courtyard, a feather eddies towar the ground, carried by the breeze. George is watching it to the ground when suddenly a gust of wind sends it soari back into the sky. George follows it with his eyes and no a man crossing between two sets. He looks like some kind hand or assistant; a working man in any case. George call him. The two men draw close and George asks him what's happening. The man takes the day's newspaper out of his p and hands it to George before walking off. George reads: Kinograph Studios stop all silent productions to work exclusively on talkies.
Despite the secretary's attempts to stop him, a furious G storms into Zimmer's office.

Zimmer is in a meeting with some men. They are probably engineers in view of the attention being given to the pla lying on the desk. Everyone is surprised by George's rude entry. The engineers seem embarrassed, but Zimmer smiles politely asks them to leave, as though asking for their understanding. As they head for the door, some of them dr their heads so as not to meet George's eyes, whereas othe look him right between the eyes but without any love lost exchange causes a strange, unpleasant feeling within him. seems embarrassed. It's perhaps due to the rudeness of hi eruption into the office, but it's more likely due to the he's been given. For the first time for ages, he has not looked at how a star is normally looked at - with respect desire and admiration - but like any ordinary man is look or, worse still, how a superfluous man is looked at. As George realizes that his status has just changed, Zimm invites him to sit down. Then speaks to him, in a friendl manner. Title card: We belong to another age, you and I, George. Nowadays, the world talks. He talks to him, looks a little embarrassed, while George takes it on the chin, not knowing how to respond. Title card: People want to see new faces. Talking faces. George reaches deep down into himself and makes an effort bring up a smile. Title card: Paramount will be delighted. They still want Zimmer responds with a pursing of the lips that is more damning than any counter argument could be. As though he' telling George he can always give it a go... George under what's happening. Zimmer is sorry. Title card: I'm sorry. The public wants fresh blood. And public is never wrong. George gets to his feet. Title card: It's me the people want and it's my films the want to see. And I'm going to give them to them. Zimmer nods with another pursing of the lips, as though h can't wait to see that. George seems very sure of himself Title card: I don't need you. Go make your talking movies I'm going to make them a beautiful film!

As George leaves in disgust, his eyes are drawn to an advertising feature representing the "new faces of Kinogr Studios". Among the medallion framed young portraits, Geo recognizes that of Peppy Miller. He glances up at Zimmer. Title card: Fresh blood... The two men exchange a last glance, then George exits.
Outside he feels a few seconds of discouragement but, as meets the gaze of the engineers waiting in the secretary' antechamber, he puffs up his chest and walks tall out of office.

Going down the stairs from the offices, he passes a laugh Peppy who is accompanied by two young and charming men, p specimens of America's golden youth. She is coming up, he going down. When she notices him, she stops, already one above of him. She has a beaming smile and is truly deligh see him. He is delighted too, although his mood is very different. Title card (him): How are you? Title card (her): Fantastic! I've been given a lead role! Isn't it wonderful?! He nods, we see in his eyes that he's terribly happy for They look at each other, she laughs. Then she fumbles in her bag for something with which to n down her telephone number on a piece of paper. It takes a while and is a little chaotic, she apologizes, but he vis takes a lot of pleasure out of watching her. She finally the number down and hands it to him, telling him to call to really call her. In response he casts a glance over to young men waiting for her higher up the stairs, and she bursts out laughing. She leans towards him to say somethi Title card: Gadgets! She looks at him flirtatiously. Then she gestures again f him to call her, and he nods, even though we think that h probably will not do so. She leaves and he watches her go before beginning his decent once more. Once at the top, s turns back to call out to George, he too has turned to lo She smiles at him, breaks into a few tap steps for old ti sake, then blows him a kiss.

He catches the kiss with a smile, pretends to make it disappear in his other hand like a magician, then shows h the inside breast pocket of his jacket as proof that he's keeping it safe and warm. She laughs loudly and goes on h way. He watches her walk away with admiration in his eyes She vanishes and George's smile takes on a note of melancholy, and then he leaves too.
George comes home. Doris is there scribbling on a magazin he takes no notice of her. When the dog jumps into his ar however, he greets it affectionately. Doris is vexed.

A while later he's running Jack through his tricks when D arrives. Title card: We have to talk, George. George smiles. Title card: Or not. She insists but he doesn't listen. He's with his dog. She gets annoyed, he doesn't answer, she ends up throwing Jac George cannot forgive her for doing so, he looks at her i disgust. She starts to cry. Title card: I'm unhappy, George. He answers without looking at her. Title card: So are millions of other people, me for insta

Thanks to a montage of shot frames, photos and press cutt we see George begin making his film, the first clap of th board that shows he's both the film's producer and direct The film is called Tears of love, and it tells the tale o English adventurer - played by himself - accompanied by a woman, an old man who looks like a professor and who is probably the father of the young woman and, lastly, an Af tribe represented as savages and whose humanity remains t proven.
